3D model of a rotating potato using HTML A-Frame
Make sure everything is in a single HTML file with embedded CSS and JS in a single code block to be used as a web app.

Certainly! Below is a simple HTML file that uses A-Frame to create a 3D model of a rotating potato. The code includes embedded CSS and JavaScript, all in a single code block. You can copy and paste this code into an HTML file and open it in a web browser to see the rotating potato.

```html
<!DOCTYPE html>
<html lang="en">
<head>
    <meta charset="UTF-8">
    <meta name="viewport" content="width=device-width, initial-scale=1.0">
    <title>Rotating Potato in A-Frame</title>
    <style>
        body {
            margin: 0;
            overflow: hidden;
        }
        a-scene {
            height: 100vh;
        }
    </style>
    <script src="https://aframe.io/releases/1.2.0/aframe.min.js"></script>
</head>
<body>
    <a-scene>
        <a-sky color="#87CEEB"></a-sky>
        
        <a-entity id="potato" geometry="primitive: sphere; radius: 1;" 
                  material="color: #D2B48C; shader: flat" 
                  position="0 1 -5">
        </a-entity>

        <a-entity light="type: ambient; color: #FFF"></a-entity>
        <a-entity light="type: directional; color: #FFF; intensity: 0.5" position="-1 2 1"></a-entity>
        
        <a-entity camera look-controls position="0 1.6 0"></a-entity>
    </a-scene>

    <script>
        // Rotate the potato entity
        const potato = document.getElementById('potato');
        let rotationSpeed = 0.5; // degrees per frame

        function rotatePotato() {
            potato.object3D.rotation.y += rotationSpeed * (Math.PI / 180); // Convert degrees to radians
            requestAnimationFrame(rotatePotato);
        }

        rotatePotato();
    </script>
</body>
</html>
```

### Instructions:
1. Copy the code above.
2. Open a text editor (like Notepad, VSCode, or any other).
3. Paste the code into the editor.
4. Save the file with a `.html` extension, for example, `rotating_potato.html`.
5. Open the saved HTML file in a web browser.

You should see a simple 3D potato model rotating in the scene. The potato is represented as a sphere with a brownish color, and the scene has a sky background. You can adjust the `rotationSpeed` variable in the JavaScript section to change how fast the potato rotates.
